full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Conservative Forces and Energy Conservation" (text) focused on "relationship between potential and kinetic energy" (text). At the top there is a simple symbolic diagram titled "energy interchange cartoon" (figure) and a short explanatory label "potential energy can change only into kinetic" (text) that presents the idea that "kinetic" appears as the only form into which potential energy can convert, and a companion label "kinetic energy converts only into potential" (text) reiterating that kinetic changes only into "potential". In the middle a schematic landscape illustration "flow contour diagram" (figure) shows water following contours as an analogy and a concise caption "difference in potential energy between two different locations in space" (text) that states the force is related to the potential difference, while another short phrase "an artifact of the potential field" (text) explicitly names the force as an artifact. At the bottom a conceptual icon "closed system symbol" (figure) is accompanied by the clarifying label "net mechanical energy is conserved in closed systems" (text) summarizing conservation whenever a conservative force acts, and the overall style of the image is clear, educational, and infographic-like.
context: A conservative force that acts on a closed system has an associated mechanical work that allows energy to convert only between kinetic or potential forms. This means that for a closed system, the net mechanical energy is conserved whenever a conservative force acts on the system. The force, therefore, is related directly to the difference in potential energy between two different locations in space, and can be considered to be an artifact of the potential field in the same way that the direction and amount of a flow of water can be considered to be an artifact of the contour map of the elevation of an area.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Nonconservative Forces Explained" (text) focused on "Macroscopic versus Microscopic Force Origins" (text). At the top there is a clear header and a small schematic pictogram labeled "A cartoon of interacting atoms" (figure) and a block of explanatory text saying "For certain physical scenarios it is impossible to model forces as being due to gradient of potentials" (text), and in the next band a comparative diagram shows a stylized macroscopic object being acted on with an icon captioned "A stylized macroscopic contact force" (figure) while a connected note reads "Macrophysical considerations give macroscopic statistical averages" (text). In the central area a detailed inset shows many tiny charges with motion arrows titled "A symbolic microstate ensemble" (figure) accompanied by a line that explicitly states "Electrostatic gradients between atoms create friction" (text), and a nearby explanatory label reads "Friction emerges independent of macroscale position vectors" (text). Further down a row of succinct statements lists types of nonconservative forces and their classification as "Nonconservative forces other than friction include contact, tension, compression, and drag" (text) and a small illustrative icon shows a hand-push and rope-pull labeled "A cartoon of macroscopic contact interactions" (figure). At the bottom a concluding caption explains reconciliation with microscopic theory saying "On sufficient microscopic detail every macroscopic force results from conservative gradients" (text). The overall style of the image is clear, instructional, and schematic.
context: For certain physical scenarios, it is impossible to model forces as being due to gradient of potentials. This is often due to macrophysical considerations that yield forces as arising from a macroscopic statistical average of microstates. For example, friction is caused by the gradients of numerous electrostatic potentials between the atoms, but manifests as a force model that is independent of any macroscale position vector. Nonconservative forces other than friction include other contact forces, tension, compression, and drag. However, for any sufficiently detailed description, all these forces are the results of conservative ones since each of these macroscopic forces are the net results of the gradients of microscopic potentials.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Macroscopic and Microscopic Forces" (text) focused on "Connections between nonconservative and conservative forces" (text). At the top there is a header explaining the analytical framework, shown as "detailed treatment with statistical mechanics" (text) and accompanied by a schematic cartoon of a magnifying glass over particles represented as a simplified group of atoms to imply analysis, shown as "\"Analytical magnifier over particles\" (figure)". In the middle a central explanatory panel states "nonconservative forces change internal energies of the system" (text) and displays a symbolic cartoon of a piston and heat arrows to indicate heat transfer, shown as "\"Piston and heat flow illustration\" (figure)". Continuing the middle narrative a secondary caption clarifies "nonconservative forces are often associated with the transfer of heat" (text). At the bottom a concluding statement cites the thermodynamic principle with the short summary "Second law of thermodynamics increases entropy in closed systems" (text) and an abstract cartoon of a rising entropy field represented by dispersed dots, shown as "\"Entropy dispersion field\" (figure)". The overall style of the image is clean, didactic, and schematic with clear icons and concise educational typography.
context: The connection between macroscopic nonconservative forces and microscopic conservative forces is described by detailed treatment with statistical mechanics. In macroscopic closed systems, nonconservative forces act to change the internal energies of the system, and are often associated with the transfer of heat. According to the Second law of thermodynamics, nonconservative forces necessarily result in energy transformations within closed systems from ordered to more random conditions as entropy increases.

full_image_caption: The image is an infographic titled "Metric and Imperial Force Units" (text) focused on "comparative force units and rare metric mass" (text). At the top a header displays the title and topic alongside a simple cartoon of a scale and weights labeled "\"balance scale with weights\" (figure)", and a bold label reading "\"the kilogram-force (kgf) is a deprecated metric force\" (text)"; beneath that a mid-section shows a stylized icon of a single kilogram with a gravity arrow captioned "\"force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram\" (text)" and a supporting illustration of a piston-like device captioned "\"kilopond as an alternative name for kilogram-force\" (text)" plus a schematic block labeled "\"symbolic force spring\" (figure) to suggest mechanical tension. Continuing downward, the next band presents a compact depiction of a mass with motion vectors captioned "\"the metric slug accelerates at 1 m·s−2 under 1 kgf\" (text)" and a small cartoon engine and wrench grouped with the text "\"used for aircraft weight and torque wrench settings\" (text)" while two additional simple icons show a heavy beam and a bolt captioned "\"sthène equals 1000 newtons\" (text)" and "\"kip equals 1000 pound-force\" (text)" and a final illustrative icon depicts a rolled-up technical paper captioned "\"archaic units still seen in specialized fields\" (text) to tie the information together. The overall style of the image is clean, informative, and schematic with concise labels and friendly flat illustrations.
context: The pound-force has a metric counterpart, less commonly used than the newton: the kilogram-force (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram of mass. The kilogram-force leads to an alternate, but rarely used unit of mass: the metric slug (sometimes mug or hyl) is that mass that accelerates at 1 m·s−2 when subjected to a force of 1 kgf. The kilogram-force is not a part of the modern SI system, and is generally deprecated; however it still sees use for some purposes as expressing aircraft weight, jet thrust, bicycle spoke tension, torque wrench settings and engine output torque. Other arcane units of force include the sthène, which is equivalent to 1000 N, and the kip, which is equivalent to 1000 lbf.
